did.unittitle:
Home and yard tour, Medford, New Jersey,
November 4, 1983

scopecontent.p: 1-3, Interior of Mrs. X's house, G-Medford; 18GT; 1, Top of pie safe with pierced tin door insets. Miniature carriages and baskets on top of the pie safe; 2, Dining room; 3, Kitchen; 4-18, Mrs. X's yard, G-Medford; 18GT. She and her husband own several acres, one of which is landscaped and depicted in these pictures. The rest are left as woods. Mrs. X has native and non-native plants in her landscape plan, but leans in preference toward native; 4-5, Elaine Thatcher and Mrs. X; 6, Elaine Thatcher and Mrs. X looking at flower bed bordered at rear by a fence reconstructed from an old one that used to separate their property from the road. The front border is of stones salvaged by Mrs. X from an old cellar. Yard accessories include wagon wheels and a round picnic table; 7-8, The family St. Bernard; 9, Bird bath centered between several flower beds. Bricks are used as borders; 10, View toward house showing flower beds edged with bricks and trellis arbor; 11-12, Pump used for watering flowers. Planters are placed around it; 13, Mrs. X and Elaine Thatcher with St. Bernard; 14, Yard swing with grape vines growing over it, situated in one corner of the yard; 15, Mrs. X pointing out succulents in a flower bed. Backdrop of old fence rails and plaster owl; 16, Closeup of small succulents, other plants and rocks by tiny pool in one flower bed; 17-18, Flower bed with sliver pinwheel set into ground to frighten groundhogs; 19, Long view across yards toward house. Compare with Frames 10 and 15.

did.unittitle:
Yard walk, Medford, New Jersey,
November 4, 1983

scopecontent.p: Logged by Elaine Thatcher on March 5, 1984. Yard of Mrs. X, G-Medford; 18GT; 1, Flower bed with rail fence backdrop and unglazed ceramic owl, also rock border. Out of focus; 2, Holly tree with old stump used decoratively in front of it; 3 Overview of Mrs. X's yard and lawn area (There are also several acres of natural woods on her property.); 4, Fieldworker Elaine Thatcher and Mrs. X look at plants; 5, Blue princess holly, bred for this region; 6-7, Grape arbor gate; 8, Trellis gate with benches; 9, Close-up of grape vines and old barrel; 10-13, Seeder or cultivator and cider press used as yard ornaments; 14, Various types of fences on Mrs. X's property. Middleground shows a low fence made of salvaged rails from another fence from their property; 15, Edge of house and small patio area used for sitting in the summer; 16, Elaine Thatcher and Mrs. X walking on path around house; 17-18 Wagon and rail fence used as yard ornaments, 19, Mrs. X and Elaine Thatcher walking in yard lawn area; 20, Flower bed with brick border and rail back border, with old wooden barrel in it

did.unittitle:
Yard walk, Medford, New Jersey,
November 4, 1983

scopecontent.p: Logged by Elaine Thatcher on March 5, 1384. In 31-32, bartender showing a game in which the winner is determined by whose name is in the square whose X crossing comes closest to being perforated by a shotgun pellet (is thus all perfectly clear?). In other words, somebody takes a pop at this sheet of paper and if your X crossing gets popped, you win. the bets are in cash, $1 a square, and the winner gets a turkey or a ham.

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazee at his cedar cutting grounds near Brookville, New Jersey,
October 7, 1983

scopecontent.p: At the cedar cutting grounds of Clifford Frazee, near G-Brookville; 53GT; 01, Live cedars growing in the swamp; 02-04, Clifford Frazee digging up old charcoal pits in the pine forests near his cutting area. These pits could be as much as 200 years old; 05-08, Cut down cedar forest with live cedars yet to be harvested in the background. In 06 and 07 boughs of cedar cover a corduroy road. They will settle in after being run over by a truck several times, forming a spongy but quite serviceable road; 09, A large cut cedar, perhaps about 75 years old; 10, Frazee's corduroy road. Bark trimmed off the cedars in the sawmill operation, along with thinner cedars too small to be used for lumber, form the base of the road while cedar boughs are piled on top to fill in the spaces; 11-20, Clifford Frazee standing on his corduroy road-in-progress, with the yet-to-be-harvested cedar forest in the background. (plant ), trees

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazee at his cedar cutting grounds near Brookville, New Jersey,
October 7, 1983

scopecontent.p: Clifford Frazee at his cedar cutting grounds near G-Brookville; 53GT; 01-03, Clifford Frazee's corduroy road (explained in CJC018); 04-07, Cedar cutting grounds; 08, Cedar stump; 09-11, Corduroy road (see CJC-018); 12-13, Cedar sprouts. The most important factor in their growth, according to Frazee, is a continued water supply. Their greatest natural enemy are the deer, who find them to be a great delicacy. The future growth of the forest basically depends upon the presence of the one and the absence of the other; 14, Cedar logs; 15, An algae-like growth on fallen cedar branches in the stream that passes through the cut forest; 16-17, Corduroy road (see CJC-018); 18, Clifford Frazee (plant), conservation, (animal); At Frazee's home in G-Waretown; 53GT; 19, Clifford Frazee next to a large cedar trunk in the back yard of his home; 20, Cedar logs. (plant)

scopecontent.p: On Route 72 east of G-Manahawkin; 56GT before getting to Ship's Bottom. 01-02, Blank road sign; 03-05, Swamp grass along Rte. 72 near the ocean. (plant); On Route 9 near G-Eaglewood Village; 46GT; 06, Eagleswood Village trailer park; Tiska house, with owner Henry Tiska, on Route 9, in G-Eagleswood; 46GT; 07-12, The house was built in the late 1800's on Long Beach Island and was moved to its present location in 1932. There are several explanations for the chair on top. Some say the previous owner opened a gas station in the thirties and used it to watch who was pilfering. Another owner was a steeplejack who used the steeple for practice, resting on the chair between climbs. For further details, see the Ocean County Observer, page 1, section C, August 14, 1983. architecture; Roadside stand in G-West Creek; 46GT; 13-14, farm market

did.unittitle:
Clamming, Rumson, New Jersey,
October 17, 1983

scopecontent.p: Clamming in Rumson, N.J. with Charles "Cholly" DeStefano of Pleasantville; 01-03, Leaving the dock; 04-05, Exchanging news with a fellow clammer; 06-08, Cholly at the wheel; 09-19, Clamming. The rake design is visible in 13 and 15. In 12 the method of attaching the pole to the rake is visible. Cholly's innovation was to move the pin attaching rake to pole further down towards the rake, thereby reducing the torque and strain on the pole. The length of the pole, as seen in 14 and 17, can be varied (e.g., the sections being held in place by hose clamps); 20, After pulling on the rake over an area, Cholly moves the boat downwards from his starting point by leaning on the pole, at the same time giving his arms a rest. (technology)

did.unittitle:
Tom Brown's "museum," Millville, New Jersey,
November 10, 1983

scopecontent.p: Tom Brown's "museum." G-Millville; 1-4, Main room, to left of entrance, looking toward left corner. Bottles and dishes, military uniform from WWI; 6-10, Main room, far left corner from entrance, showing old stove, bottles, wasp's nest, tools, etc.; 11-12, Passageway room leading directly from entrance to back door, display on left wall with bottles and Indian implements. did.unittitle:
Corking, Port Norris, New Jersey,
March 21, 1984

scopecontent.p: Corking G-Port Norris; , See PFP-84-FJC0321 for more information; 1-6, Larry Baglio; 7, Close-up showing irons and mesquite corking mallet; 8, The hooked piece called a " hook ," the straight piece a "reefer" (For "reefing" out old caulking), the triangular pieces are all various types of "corking irons." The little black thing in the center is a "finger stall."; 9-20, Corking operation. The cotton goes in first, followed by the "oakum." A sharp edged iron is used to catch and stuff the material in the cracks, ablunt one to tamp it down. Continued on PFP-84-CJC-017.

did.unittitle:
Interview with Harvey and Delores Webb, and yard tour, Chatsworth, New Jersey,
September 19, 1983

scopecontent.p: Webb home G-Chatsworth; 27GT; 0-1A, Christine Cartwright and Dolores Webb beside the Henry Webb home, Chatsworth; 2A-3A, Henry Webb home; 4A-5A, Vegetable and flower gardens, Henry and Harvey Webb homes, Chatsworth; 5A-8A, Scarecrow, Henry Webb garden; 9A-16A, Chicken coop under Concord grape arbor, Henry Webb garden, and closeups of chickens; 17A-21A, Long shots of Henry Webb house and gardens; 22A-23A, Workshop shared by Henry and Harvey Webb, used for dismantling complex metal objects to separate different types of metal for sale to junkyards, and for household construction and repairs; 24A-26A, Motorboat, fiberglass, sixteen feet Jong. Used by Harvey Webb for fishing on the Mullica River for perch and other fish for family use; 27A-29A, Rabbit hutch containing three does and a buck, being raised as pets by Mrs. Harvey Webb. The babies are occasionally sold to neighbors or pet stores; 30A-33A, Metallic goods salvaged from roadside and forest dump sites by Harvey Webb, being prepared for delivery to junk dealers.

did.unittitle:
Interview with Harvey and Delores Webb, and yard tour, Chatsworth, New Jersey,
September 19, 1983

scopecontent.p: G-Chatsworth; 27GT; 0, signature shot; 1-3, Dolores Webb shows Christine Cartwright the area used by her husband and father-in-law to trim the leaves from cattails after harvesting, to prepare them for sale to wholesale florists for use in arrangements and decorative pieces. In the center, a broken cement mixer being mended by Harvey Webb; 4-14, Closeups and long shots of the Harvey Webb home, showing rock walls under construction by Harvey and Henry Webb. The rocks are collected as they are discarded by construction workers at sites where Harvey works as a heavy equipment operator, and set in place over a tar paper foundation with cement. The top of the wall will be finished with narrow wooden planking to provide a straight edge, which will seal easily against the eaves. The rock is being added for insulation, but is also decorative; 15-16, medium shots of Harvey Webb home; 17-18, Jeremiah and Joshua, nephews of Harvey and Dolores Webb, play near the house; 19-23, Mrs. Evelyn Webb Barnard hangs out laundry in her parents' garden assisted by her son Jeremiah; 24-25, An old Franklin stove used for burning plastic inculation off copper wire, stored near the workshop; 26-27, The "hog killing tree," showing noose suspended from branch where hog's hind leg is caught during butchering; 28-30, Jeremiah Barnard doing acrobatics on a treebranch in his grandfather's garden; 31-36, "Bee gum," a section of a felled tree containing a natural beehive, set under a tree in Henry Webb's garden.

Putiri's home, Elwood, New Jersey,
November 17, 1983

scopecontent.p: First of five holders with Putiris this date. All photographs on this sheet at Putiri 's home on US Route 30 G-Elwood; 12GT; 1-2, At the kitchen table: Sal Sr, Sal Jr, Elaine Thatcher, Sue Samuelson; 3-4, Cedar bases for cedar crosses (when completed, decorations are added to the wood seen here); 5-10, Photographs of S al Sr's and Emma's wedding. Emma or "Phini's" maiden name was Josephine Palmieri. The pictures are from Sal Sr.'s wedding album; 5-6, Bride and groom coming down the aisle preceded by Gracie Ricci (is she titled "flower girl?"). The elaborate altar discussed on the tape (either an "SS" or "ET" number) concerns the altar visible in this photo; 7-8, Family group at the wedding: Carmen Palmieri (bride's brother), Nevicella DeMarco Palmieri (bride's mother), Josephine Palmieri Putiri (bride), Sal Sr. (groom), Martha Russo Putiri (groom's mother), and Salvatore Putiri (groom's father); 9-10, bride and groom; 11-13, Putiri's living room; 14-18, Sal Putiri Sr.

did.unittitle:
Ruins at the Amatol Plant near Putiris; Emma's market, Ellwood, New Jersey,
November 17, 1983

scopecontent.p: Second of five holders with Putiris this date. All locations: G-Ellwood; 12GT; 1-12, "Ruins" at the Amatol Plant near Putiris (more or less behind their house in the woods) where the boys used to play; 8, Same, an opening to a covered hole of some sort; 9, R.P. and E.T.; 10, Sue Samuelson, Ralph Putiri, and Elaine Thatcher; 11-12, Sign for Amatol site; 14-20, Part of a series of shots of signs for Emma's market. The photos are continued on CCF-014. The signs are a series that a northbound driver on US Route 30 sees as he approaches the market. They were painted (when? probably during the last four or five years, to guess) by Sal Jr. Sal was proudest of the first sign, with the corncupia (see also closeup; frames 13-14). Wide shots intermingled with the closer shots will provide orientation.

did.unittitle:
Interview with Joe Reid, Jack Cervetto, Tom Darlington, New Jersey,
April 5, 1984

scopecontent.p: 1-5, Various views of scale model of garvey, made by Joe Reid. This one has a cabin on it, with bunks and a table inside. It is flat-bottomed, for use in the shallow water of Barnegat Bay; 6-12, Various views of scale model of V-bottom garvey, in progress. Planking and fittings are replicated exactly to scale; 13, Flat-bottom garvey, without cabin. The old boats never had keels, which require close attention to depth of channels. Keels can carry more salt; 14-15, Reid working on the flat-bottom garvey with sandpaper; 16, Joe Reid and his wife, Gladys; 17, Gladys Reid with mounted photograph of a pet deer she had for years when she first was married; G-Waretown: 53GT; 18, Photograph, held by Jack and Pearl Cervetto, of foxhunters in G-Woodland Township; 27GT in the 1930s. Her father, Bill Holloway, is among them. They are, to the best of her recollection, left to right: Tom Mick, an unidentified woman, Clarence "Bull" Stafford, Hank Corlies (related to the famed Rube Corlies, sneakbox builder and decoy carver), Alfred Stevenson of Chatsworth, Harold Stevenson who is supposedly still alive, Randall "Snap" Stafford, two more unidentified people, Ward Holloway, Bill Holloway, Joe Holloway, and Charles Holloway; 19-20, Photo of black and white aerial shot of the bogs at G-Buffins' Meadows; 21GT, engineered by Tom Darlington. They are regarded as being exceptionally well-designed, to make the most efficient use of a low water supply and the best of the availabIe technology

did.unittitle:
Blueberry harvest at Thompson's, Chatsworth, New Jersey, and Retreat, New Jersey,
July 1984

scopecontent.p: Introduction to the Blueberry Slide Series: CDM-015-CDM-020. Our farm is located in two locations in the Pinelands National Reserve: Chatsworth and Retreat. The Chatsworth location consists of twenty acres and was cleared by my Grandfather Thompson and my father. The other location is Retreat and is located outside of Vincentown where my family lives. The slides do not show two important aspects of the business. First the ethic diversity of the pickers and the numbers involved. We hire approximately 40-80 hand pickers a day and they come form many locations in the county. Also the mechanical nature of picking is not represented. This process occurs at the end of the season and machines are used to strip the bushes of their remaining fruit. This step was accelerated in the late 60's and early 70's when labor shortage and minimum wage payments were being inforced. It was during this period that our farm was electrified and we bought a large sorting machine and individual harvesting machines. Up to that point most of the sorting was done with wire screens with berries that were hand knocked a much older process. The co-operative that we send our berries to is also an important aspect of the business. This was started by members of my grandmother Thompson's generation with the help of Elizabeth White. Most of the old growers in the co-operative are relatives of the early members and continue in the tradition of marketing collectively; 1-8, Team of two kids picking. One picks one side of the bush and one the other. The kids are from the local school in Chatsworth. The kids are picked up in the morning and ride in the back of the pickup and are returned in the early afternoon. An average of 20 to 40 students come each morning and represent about 30% of our pickers. The girl in the striped shirt is pickingwith both hands and dropping the berries in a can that is tied around her waist; 9-11, Cluster of a Weymouth variety, an older cultivar that is the earliest berry to ripen; 12-13, Cedar trays with added pine rails. The trays were purchased through the co-operative and the rails were made at a hardware store in Vincentown (Halls). The trays were made at a local sawmill and sold to growers. The rails are designed to increase the height between each flat or tray in order to not damage the berries on the bottom when stacking on the truck. The trays are filled with pint cups made of paper pulp that are also purchased from the co-operative. The picker fills the trays themselves and usually picks two at a time then turn them in to the person at the truck that is waiting to haul in any full ones; 14-15, Close up shot of the berries in the tray. The light colored berry that stands out is one that is not quiet ripe. It will probably be picked out by the packer on turned over so its ripest side is displayed to the consumer. The pickers are instructed to not pick green ones or one not quite ripe. Therefore there are people in the Thompson family walking through the field supervising the operation; 16-19, A brother and sister partner picking. Brad Thompson picks these two up in the morning on my way through Chatsworth. In the back ground another team is working the other way and will soon finish the row.

did.unittitle:
Blueberry harvest at Thompson's, Chatsworth, New Jersey, and Retreat, New Jersey,
July 1984

scopecontent.p: 1-3, Bending on one knee is one technique which saves stress on the back and is demonstrated in this series; 4-5, Brad Thompson is giving a ticket to a picker who has finished a flat. This transaction usually occurs at the truck which is at the end of the row on the dirt road. The ticket is one half inch by by two and has printed on one side, S Thompson, twelve pints. It is red and is turned in at the end of the day for cash. A usual trick is to see how far the pickers can get me to come into the field in order to save them a few steps. My trick of course is to see if I can get them to carry the tray to the tailgate of the truck. Generally I only help older people who have a hard time moving which of course brings us to another trick; 6-8, Debbie Miller Joins the team to help them finish the row. Most of the pickers have moved to another field and Thompsons are trying to finish this field and move all the remaining pickers to the next area at the same time. Debbie Miller is also a student of Brad Thompson's brothers at the local school; 9-10, Picker walking tray to the truck to receive ticket. This picker is a student at Trenton State and will finish in a year or so. She comes and picks with her family and is from Willingboro a Levitt-planned development near the Delaware just across from Levittown, PA; 11-13, Waiting at the end of the row to pick up flats. Brad hollers each time he stops the truck, "any full ones" and this will prompt people to start carrying in the trays. Some days it is hard to get people to respond. They may be hurrying to pick a certain number by a certain time and are reluctant to stop and bring them down. When picking the Weymouth things are usually slow. This particular variety does not crop as well recent varieties and pickers can not pick as many as they do later in the season; 14-20, Unloading the truck and puting full flats on carts to be rolled into the packing house and packed. Slide 18 shows the "hock" which was discovered several years ago when a hoe was used to slide the berries off the truck. The blade of the hoe broke and the curved end remaine'd, This device saves one from climbing on and off the truck. All unloading can be done from the ground. Before the hock and the increase in production, Brad remembers that as a small child his Job was to push or carry the trays from the bck of the truck to the front so his brother could unload them.

did.unittitle:
Blueberry harvest at Thompson's, Chatsworth, New Jersey, and Retreat, New Jersey,
July 1984

scopecontent.p: 1-5, Continuation of unloading the truck. The wrapped brown tan package is a box of pints which will be delivered to the truck. Part of the routine is to pickup flats and drop off supplies. The long narrow green strip that runs parallel to the sand road is a drainage ditch that helps regulate the water table; 6-7 Views of the packing house from north. The original section or two story structure was built by my father with the help of Juber Stephenson in the early forties. The packing house is made of cedar clapboards and probably came form my grandfather Thompson's saw mill. Barley noticeable under the porch roof are windows that can be covered by by cedar awnings. The awnings retrack and cover opening and are typical of most packing houses in the area. The "A" frame timbers are reinforcements and a modern garage door replaces the somewhat larger origin al; 8, View of the packing house form the east showing "L" shaped porch, benches and picnic table. This area is reserved for the pickers and acts as a lunch room; 9-15, Unloading truck with the assistance of Peter Boden who has been our shed boy for three years. He too is a student from the local school and follows his three older brothers as shed boy. This is a very prestigious position to hold and is reserved for the best works and pickers. The responsibilties are numerous. He tends to the packers, helps unload the truck, fills jugs of water and takes them to the pickers, at time picks up flats at the end of the row and does all that my mother, brother or my self ask him to do. He is fourteen and can drive the truck. This of course is the envy of his contemporaries and one perk of the job that is most sought; 16-19, Peter loads the truck with empty trays that I will take and unload in the field. Peter prefers to load them in piles and I would rather have them lower so they would be jerked off the truck. I usually win.

did.unittitle:
Blueberry harvest at Thompson's, Chatsworth, New Jersey, and Retreat, New Jersey,
July 1984

scopecontent.p: 1-3, Bluecrop a variety that crops well and is highly favored by consumers. This variety is ripening as we pick the Weymouth and gernerally motivates the pickers to finish the earlier varieties so they can begin picking the Bluecrop. This shot was taken at our other farm in Retreat which is about three to four days ahead of Chatsworth in the ripening cycle; 4-5, Beverly Allen Adams and Chad Adams packing. Beverly Adams is also a local school teacher in Chatsworth who has been working for us in the summers. Beverly is pulling the pint out of the try and prepares the pint for packing; 6-9, Packing house and surrounding area dramatize the blue and white sky and the low green horizon of the hedgerows; 10-16, Jack (John Wesley) Thompson making the cardboard container that the blueberries will be shipped in. They come in bundles of 275 from the co-operative and cost 35 cents a piece. Under the table is Tuck (Tuckahoe IV) who follows my father where ever he goes; 17, View form inside the packing house looking out; 18-19, Blueberries in hand to accentuate the color.

did.unittitle:
Blueberry harvest at Thompson's, Chatsworth, New Jersey, and Retreat, New Jersey,
July 1984

scopecontent.p: 1-7, Chad Adams packing. He is demonstrating the begining to end cycle of packing one pint. First the pint is removed from the field tray and topped. Topping is the step that assures that there are not green berries, leaves of rotten berries and that the pint is fully rounded. In slide two you can see Chad's right index finger and thumb act as pincers to remove an unwanted berry. Next Chad has reached and gotten a piece of cellophane and centered the sheet on the pint. Then the packing frame is place over the sheet and moved over the berries wrapping the corners around the pint. A rubber band is stretched over the pint and hold the cellophane on the pint. Finally Chad put the packed pint in the cardboard box. The process is continued until twelve pints are packed and the flat is placed on a cart and the cycle begins again. Chad is paid 22 cents for each flat he packs. Usually he can pack between 16-20 flats in an hour; 8-10, Chad Adams and his mother Beverly packing. The boxes that line the porch are used for mechanical picking and are stored under the porch until they are needed; 11-12, View of the packing house form the west. this view shows the wooden awnings that are opened and closed each day. This typical design of packing houses are being replaced by concrete block building which lack the cooling nature of cedar. With awnings porches and double story the packing house remains remarkably cool even in the hottest weather. Also the concrete floor retains coolness that it slowly disseminates during the day; 13-19, Series of the unloading and loading process from inside of the packing house. The cart is loaded and taken to the side of a packer who will take one flat at a time and pack. The packed flat will be placed on a similar cart thus limiting the times one has to pick up each flat. Peter after the truck is unloaded will put empty trays that the packers have packed back on the truck and the cycle is completed.

did.unittitle:
Blueberry harvest at Thompson's, Chatsworth, New Jersey, and Retreat, New Jersey,
July 1984

scopecontent.p: 1-2, Finished products as they looked stacked on the cart. Each cart will be stacked with forty flats making the tally at the end of the day easy and accurate. Each box is stamped with the growers number and size. Our number is 46 and the size is moon. That determination is made by counting how may berries there are in a cup. Moon is a small berry and counts from 90 berries to the cup on up. Crown is the larger berry and counts from 90 on down; 3-5, Flat as it appeared in the field. At the end of the day all berries are turned into the truck reguardless if they are filled. A ticket or combination of tickets is given to the picker. In this case the picker probably received tickets for ten pints. That would be two five pint tickets. The old flat tickets are in denominations of five pint tickets and one pint tickets there in allowing for payment of any number between 1 and 11 pints. The cans are turned in and people are paid under the porch by my mother.

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazee at North Branch cedar swamp, New Jersey,
October 7, 1983

scopecontent.p: G-North Branch; 49GT Cedar cutting; 01-02, Cliff and Steve begin to trim limbs from trees they have felled; 03-07, Trees at point of cut; 08-24, Cliff and Steve trimming limbs from trees; 25-27, Limbs are cut flush to the tree trunk; 28-29, Steve uses 8 foot stick to measure trees for cuts every 16 feet; 30, Chain saw on log; 31, Steve lifts log into place for cutting; 32-33, Cliff making his way through the brush; 34, Cliff carrying a log close to the road where it can be picked up on his next work day in the swamp; 35-36, Cliff looking for any trees that still need to be trimmed. This is one of the few times he or Steve paused in their work. Continued on PFP-83-BMO215661-05

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazee at North Branch cedar swamp, New Jersey,
October 7, 1983

scopecontent.p: These photographs document a day's cedar cutting G-North Branch; 49GT. See also PFP-83-CM0001-004, PFP-83-RM0014-016, and PFP-83-BJC-216395-06 and 11. For photos of cedar logs once they are delivered to the sawmill see PFP-83-CMO005-006. For documentation of cedar delivered to Joe Reid to build boats see Tom Carroll's logs; 0A-1, Steve turns logs around so butts (heavier ends) can be placed at cab end of truck; 1A-2, Steve removes cable from logs just hoisted on truck; 2A-3, Steve shoves same logs into place; 3A-4, Steve pulls cable to wrap it around net group of logs. Cliff operates the winch controls from the other side of the truck. See below, #5A-6; 4A-5, Steve adjusts cable at end of logs; 5A-6, Cliff operating winch; 6A-11, Cliff operating winch. To the side of the truck lie logs that will be hoisted onto the load later when truck is moved down the corduroy road; 11A-14, As load gets higher, Steve must climb on top to adjust position of logs and remove hook and cable in order to pull cable to the next set of logs. Here he performs those operations; 14A-16, Underexposed shots looking west from loading location down the road we drove in to get to the loading area; 16A-17, Cable has been adjusted to center of logs once the logs are hoisted to lean on the truck bed. Here Steve looks for the best location for this set of logs; 17A-19, Logs parallel and close to the truck can have cable put right in the center and can then be hoisted right up; 19A, Logs with cable caught underneath them; 20A-21, Steve guides logs into place; 21A-22, Cable pulled a good distance away from truck (up to 150 feet). Note dense brush; 22A-24, Steve watches as Cliff winches in a number of large logs. Steve must gauge correct speed because Cliff cannot always see obstacles in the logs' path; 24A-28, Loading of large log toward the top of the load; 28A-34, Cliff hands 3-4 inch diameter logs to Steve to place at top of the load. These will be used for fenceposts. The cedar cutting operation photographs continue on PFP-83- BMO215661-01 and BMO215661-05.

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazzee at North Branch cedar swamp, New Jersey,
October 7, 1983

scopecontent.p: G-North Branch; 49GT This is a continuation of BMO215661-02 and 01; 00, Cliff pushes log toward corduroy road. Logs are turned end over end to get them to the side of the road where they can be hoisted on to the truck easily; 01, Logs lined up along the side of the road for pick up on the next workday. Cliff and Steve throw branches on the road, the final layer of a corduroy road; 02-16, Steve and Cliff cut trees. Cliff stands behind the tree while Steve notches it on one side and cuts through on the other. As the tree begins to fall Cliff helps by pushing it. Before cutting they check to make sure the wind is favorable. As you can see the trees are chosen so that they fall into an area already cleared and toward the road; 17-20, Steve and Cliff begin to trim the branches off the trees once they are on the ground; 21-22, A line of trees that have just been cut. I am standing at the road; 23-26, Cliff picking up and throwing branches onto the road, after which he pauses briefly before continuing; 27, (Description accidentally deleted; cannot find hard copy--SS); 28, Steve walks from one place to another on logs. He did this often, and it is not easy. Again think of the amount of energy necessary to Just walk around in a swamp covered with logs and brush, let alone work there with axe and chain saw blades; 29, Steve trims a log; 30, Steve walking on a log with measuring stick in one hand and an axe in the other; 31-36A, Steve measures logs while Cliff cuts them into 16 foot lengths.

did.unittitle:
Meeting with Bill Lucas at his home and shop, Pemberton, New Jersey,
October 21, 1983

scopecontent.p: 01-02, Clicks to advance the film went too far. No picture intended; 03, Stump at the top of a pile of logs in Bill' s front yard. G-Pemberton; 21GT This epitomized Bill, a person who dropped by said. It is a walnut stump, I think, and Bill likes to work with walnut; 04-05, Bill's dog. His mother asked me to take a picture of the dog for him; 06, Bill's 1955 Chevy truck that he uses to haul logs; 07-08, Pile of logs on the house side of the driveway. In 08 is Bill's mother. He and his mother and father live in the house in the background; 09-12, A few shots of Bill's sign along the road; 13, Bill's camper that he takes down to North Carolina on gem hunting expeditions; 14, Piles of logs in back yard behind Bill's shop; 15-18, Back of shop from the yard. What we are looking at is the sawmill that Bill uses to mill the logs after they sit in his yard for a year or so; 19, Two logs that reminded me of a canon. Butts are painted to protect them from rot; 20, Another shot of the sawmill; 21, Painted end of log to prevent rot; 22-24, View after turning left at end of road in 14; 25, View turning right at end of 14; 26, Same position as 22-24, but focusing on the right side of the road; 27, Same position as 25, but looking on the left side of the road; 28-30, Yard from same position as 26, a longer view; 31-35, More shots of sawmill, taken from top of a pile of logs; 36-36A, Close-ups of sawmill

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazee at his cedar cutting grounds near Brookville, New Jersey,
October 14, 1983

scopecontent.p: These photographs attempt to document the cedar cutting operation of Clifford Frazee and his son Steve. The pictures are arranged in the order of steps taken by the Frazees. For further information please refer to PFP-83-FM01014 and the corresponding black and white contact shoots. G-Forked River; 49GT; 1-6, Shots of the land being clear-cut by the Frazees; 1, looks into the area to be cut next; 2-4, look north from the shadows of the area to be cut next, 5-6, look west, the direction from which we entered the cedar swamp; 7, The truck with winch used to hoist the logs onto the truck. Steve is on the truck and Cliff is looking for the next log to go on; 8, Steve wraps the hooked cable around a group of logs near the butt of the log, preparing them for hoisting up to the truck; 3, The logs are on the truck, and Steve unhooks the cable; 10, Steve pulls the cable (as Cliff gives it slack from the controls) in order to get the cable to the next group of logs; 11-12, The pulley, at the end of the beam, through which the cable runs that is used to hoist the logs; 13-14, Logs lined up by the side of the corduroy road that are positioned to make the hoisting as easy as possible; 15, The butt end of a cedar log; 16-20, Cliff hands the logs 3-5 inches in diameter to Steve to be placed at the top of the load. These logs will be used for fenceposts. ( The cutting process continues on PFP-83-CM0002.)

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazzee at North Branch cedar swamp, New Jersey,
October 14, 1983

scopecontent.p: This is a continuation of the cedar cutting process began in PFP-83-CM0001. G-Forked River; 49GT; 1-4, The truck loaded and ready to be driven to the sawmill later when the next steps of the cutting operation are completed; 5-8, Trees that have just been felled. (Refer to BLOG to see the cutting of those trees). This is the next step after loading the truckwith logs that had been cut on the last cutting day; 9, Limbs of felled trees must be trimmed. Cliff begins this, the most time consuming of the steps in the cedar cutting process; 10-15, Cliff using an axe to cut limbs off trees; 16-18, Steve and Cliff cutting limbs; 19-20,: Steve cutting limbs. (Continued on CMO003)COLOR PHOTO LOG

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazee at his cedar cutting grounds near Brookville, New Jersey,
October 14, 1983

scopecontent.p: This file is a continuation of PFP-83-CM0001/002. Please note the depth of foliage, and the balance necessary to work in this swamp while knee deep in trees and tree debris. G-Forked River; 49GT; 1, Steve pauses while cutting limbs with axe and throws limb toward corduroy road; 2-3,: Logs after limbs have been cut off. Notice that limbs are cut so that log has no stubs afterward, just one smooth surface. A very difficult operation; 4, Axe placed in stump when not in use; 5-6, The thin brown stick in these pictures Is 8 feet long and used by Steve to measure trees, once the limbs are cut the off they are logs; 7-9, Steve uses the stick to measure logs in this series. Every two lengths he marks the log by notching it with his axe. (Refer to PFP-83-BMO215661-05); 10, When enough logs are notched, they are cut into 16 foot lengths with a chainsaw. Here Cliff prepares to cut; 11, Cliff cutting horizontally; 12, Cliff holding chainsaw vertically to make cut; 13-14, Cliff begins a cut when point of cut is in the air by cutting from the top down. In 14 he finishes the cut from the bottom up so the sawi won't bind in the log, thus avoiding possible injury; 15, Cliff trims limbs while Steve cuts lengths with his chain saw. This is as close as they get to each other while cutting; 16, Steve walking on log and looking for next log to cut; 17, Steve cutting with chainsaw while standing on brush; 18-20, Steve cutting with chain saw while standing on logs. (This part of the cutting operation is continued on PFP-83-CM0004.)

did.unittitle:
Clifford Frazee at his cedar cutting grounds near Brookville, New Jersey,
October 14, 1983

scopecontent.p: This is a continuation of CMO 001-003; 1-4, Steve cutting with chain saw with left leg forward on log and right leg back on ground or brush; 5, Steve using chain saw with right leg back and up on log and left leg forward in brush. This series is designed to show kinesis of cutting logs with chain saw. Both Cliff and Steve, his son, hold the trgger handle with their right hands and the upper handle with their left; 6-9, Before the logs are cut to length (and afterward) the are taken to the corduroy road and placed on top of the logs there. This series shows Cliff doing just that. (For a description of the corduroy road see FMO001); 10, Steve carrying brush to corduroy road; 11, A blurred picture of limbs on road; 12-13, Limbs on roadbed. Also in this picture are 16 foot long cedar logs that have been flipped end over end or dragged to the side of the road, where they can be hoisted on the truck the next time the Frazees come to the cedar swamp. Also in 13 the end of the corduroy road can bo seen. Cliff brings a maple or gum tree that they have cut down to use in the road bed; 14, Steve moves log toward road; 15-17, Logs lined up by the side of the road for pickup next time. This marks the end of slides on cedar cutting by Cliff and Steve Frazee.

did.unittitle:
Sawmill; Cedar cutting, Forked Mill, New Jersey,
October 21, 1983

Sawmilling of cedar log, New Jersey,
October 14, 1983

scopecontent.p: This is a continuation of PFP-83-CMO005 on the cutting of a cedar log; 1, The log returning to starting position as Steve pushes lever all the way to the left; 2, Similar to #1, but from further outside the shed; 3, Once the log has returned to its starting position, Steve lines it up for the second pass; 4, Second pass through blade; 5, Steve's brother holds board to ensure an accurate cut; 6, The completion of the second cut as seen from outside the shed, behind Steve at the lever; 7, Steve begins to move the lever to the left so log can return to starting position. This marks the end of this series; 8-11, These shots show cuts along the vertical sides of what may end up as a 4x8 or two 4x4's. The opposite end of the tracks can be seen also, and the cable that pulls the carriage along the track. The slabs from earlier cuts are to the right of the track. Also note the shoot, diagonal board on the left, that takes the sawdust from pit under tho blade to the truck shown in PFP-83-CMO005; 12-14, Here the blade is cutting the horizontal edges of what might become a 4x8 inch board; 15-17, The log sitting on the carriage and being lined up (#17) just before passing it through the blade. These are similar to shots in CMO005 but are taken from inside the shed at the point where the log stops at the end of a cut before returning to its starting position; 18, Steve fills the radiator (I think); 19-20, The saw blade and fan belt assembly, with (in #20) lever mechanism for moving cable that pulls the carriage with the log on it through the blade. REMAINING PICTURES IN THIS SEQUENCE ARE IN PFP-83-CM0016.

did.unittitle:
Trip to Steve Frazee's sawmill, Forked River, New Jersey,
October 14, 1983

scopecontent.p: Visit to Steve Frazee's sawmill, G-Forked River; 49GT; 1, Yard to right of mill showing driveway entrance to mill; 2, Stack of slabs used for log cabins in the woods. I think this was cut for a man who wanted to build a cabin, but he never picked up the lumber; 3-4, View looking down the 4x12s that support logs before they are roll ed onto the saw carriage; 5, Another view of logs waiting to be cut with slabs in foreground. These are not slabs used in corduroy road. These are not scrap, but thicker for siding a building; 6: View looking in shed at the wheel that the fan belt runs around; 7-8, A look at the mill and carriage that carries the log through the saw blade; 9; Steve adjusts log as it passes through the blade; 10: Steve looks for next log, while brother Butch stacks slabs; 11-12, A 4x4 in the making; 13, The rails the carriage rides on seen from the other end away from the blade. The cable between the rails pulls the carriage; 14-15, Two more shots from the same end as # 13.COLOR PHOTO LOG

did.unittitle:
First visit to Bill Lucas' woodworking shop, South Pemberton, New Jersey,
October 21, 1983

scopecontent.p: Bill Lucas' woodworking shop G-South Pemberton: 21GT; 1-2, Bill Lucas and his mother standing in the driveway between his shop and the house where he and his mother and father live. A visitor present at the time said that the background of logs and especially that enormous walnut stump was the perfect image to associate with Bill and his work; 3, The 1955 Chevy truck that Bill uses to haul logs when he goes to a person's land to remove a tree, often a walnut tree, and cut it up; 4, Bill 's father, who is 95 years old, as he prepares to go with Bill to pick up some lumber; 5, Bill's shop complex as seen from the top of a pile of logs. His house would be on the far side of the shop. I am standing in a yard filled with oak, walnut, map le, etc. logs. The shed seen dierectly houses the sawmill that his father used to run when Bill was a child. Bill now uses it for all his milling; 6-8; Close-up of the sawmill; 9, View with back to sawmill, out into the yard where Bill stacks his logs for a year until they are milled. This and the next few photos show Bill's arrangement of his yard, and how he stacks logs. No, not necessarily according to type of wood; 10, Same position a few feet further down; 11, Butt of log in #10 at right, at mid-depth of the photo. Bill paints the butts to avoid rot; 12, A right turn at the log of #11 brings you to this view and Rte. 532? that passes in front of Bill's shop and house; 13, A left: turn at #11 brings this pile of logs into view; 14: Painted butts of two logs in yard in front of sawmill; 15-16, Rotting log in yard in front of sawmill.

did.unittitle:
Second visit to Lee family: trip to cranberry and blueberry fields and packing houses, New Jersey,
November 19, 1983

scopecontent.p: Trip to berry fields and packing houses with Stephen and Abbot Lee G-Chatsworth Road; 27GT (Rt. 563); 1-2, Stephen (on right) and Abbot stand next to cutting beds in nursery section of farm next to the packing house; 3, Southeast of packing houses; 4, North side of packing house; 5, Building next to packing house; 6, Standing in front of packing house looking across Rt. 563 at blueberry fields; 7, Bog iron near white buildings in Frame 6; 8-10, A concrete "gate"--the gate most commonly used by the Lees now (for water). The concrete pipe would be under water and through the dam; 11-15, Blueberry fields across from the packing houses.

did.unittitle:
Interview with Darlingtons at their cranberry farming operation, Whitesbog, New Jersey,
November 18, 1983

scopecontent.p: Visit to the Darlington's cranberry operation G-Whitesbog; 21GT; 1, The Darlington's off ice and metal shop; 2, The right side of the road standing from the same spot as Frame 1; 3-5, The bogs in the distance of Frame 2. You can see these near-perfect bogs from the office window and pass some of them (Frame 3) when driving to the office; 6-7, Fieldworker Mary Hufford talking to Mark Darlington with shed holding cranberry boxes behind and to the left of them; 8, One of the Darlington's machine sheds; 9-10, Worker's houses; 11-13, Blueberry harvester invented by Tom Darlington; 14, Close up of the shafts that vibrate and knock berries off branches and down to metal leaves below, where a fan blows them to the conveyor belt on bottom right; 15, Conveyor belt to carry cranberries from bog to truck; 16-17, Harvester; 18-20, Floating cranberry harvester invented by Tom Darlington. This machine has the advantage of not ruining the bog by driving over it with wheels.

did.unittitle:
Interview with Mark Darlington, Whitesbog, New Jersey,
November 18, 1983

scopecontent.p: Visit to the Darlington's cranberry operation G-Whitesbog; 21GT; 1, Looking out from the machine shed at boxes used to carry cranberries; 2-6, More shots of cranberry boxes; 7-8, The sorting machine; 9-15, Shots of the plane, the fertilizer, and the loading of the fertilizer onto the plane that the Darlingtons rant to fertilize their fields; 16-17, Blueberry fields as seen when I turned me back on the plane.

G-New Gretna; 15GT; 5, Map on wall of gun club; 6, Door leading to bunk toom from living room; 7, Banner on wall of living room; 8-10, Main room (living room) looking toward bunk room; 11, Main room, pivoting to look at front door and fireplace. It looks like a lot of the action occurs at that end possibly; at least when it's not Deer Week and crowded; 12, George Heinrichs standing in bunk room; 13-16, More shots of bunk room. I am standing at the door from the main room.

did.unittitle:
Interview with Clara Paolino, Ancora, New Jersey,
October 11, 1983

scopecontent.p: G-Ancora; 33GT; 1A: Clara Paolino in her kitchen; 2A, Elaine Thatcher; 3A-5A, Clara Paolino and Elaine Thatcher; 6A-7A, Clara Paolino; 8A-9A, Clara Paolino's kitchen; 10A, Clara Paolino holding jar of bread and butter pickles; 11A-12A, Clara Paolino holding a plastic bag that contains the recipe and seasonings for her pickles; 13A, Recipe (in plastic bag) for Clara's bread and butter pickles. Recipe reads: Bread and Butter Pickles, Clara, 25 pickles (meaning cucumbers?), 6 or 8 onions, Make a boiling solution, 5 cups white vinegar, 5 cups sugar, 1/2 cup salt, 1/2 cup mustard seed, 1 tsp tumeric, 1 tbsp celery seed, Make this come to a boil for 1 min. Then put sliced pickles and onions in for about 1 min then put in hot jars and top them tight; 14A-15A, Clara opening plastic bags of basil she keeps in her kitchen freezer; 16A-17A, Clara showing freezer package of eggplant; 18A-19A, Clara sorting through recipes; 20A, Clara's back and the tape recorder; 21A-23A, Clara sorting through recipes; 24A, Basket of artificial fruit on Clara's kitchen table; 25A, View of area behind house from kitchen table; 26A, Signature shot; 27A-28A, Clara sorting through recipes (focus on hands); 29A, Clara sorting recipes (focus on her); 30A-31A, Cranberry sauce home canned in a Tang jar; 32A, Clara pouring cherry brandy from jug; 33A, Cherry brandy in jug on kitchen counter; 34A-35A, Clara and her cellar freezer; 36A-37A (37A is unmarked.), Shelves of home canned goods in Clara's cellar.

scopecontent.p: 2-37, Woods walk with George and Helen Zimmer G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT. We walked through woods originally owned by Helen's family, the Ramps. (Helen Zimmer later told us that she calls them "beggar lice.") Plants; 30A, Old cabin behind a newer house. The owner of the dam could not afford the upkeep on it and got no support from locals to keep it in good repair, so he drained the reservoir.

did.unittitle:
Woods walk, Egg Harbor City, New Jersey,
November 14, 1983

scopecontent.p: 2-37, Woods walk with George and Helen Zimmer on their land. The land was part of the original holdings of Helen's family, the Ramp family. We walked through her land as well as that of her brothers and sisters. G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT; 2, Helen Zimmer and Sue Samuelson walking in the woods; 3, Shower at western boundary of Zimmers' back lawn (not their property boundary). The shower is useful for preliminary clean-ups after being out in the swamps; 4, Closeup of Zimmer pumphouse foundation; 5, George Zimmer and Sue Samuelson; 6, Hoity plant; 7, Birdhouse made of plastic pipe; 8, Helen Zimmer and Sue Samuelson walking away from camera; 9, Hudsonia; 10, Young pines and oak; 11, George Zimmer, Sue Samuelson, and Helen Zimmer walk away from camera along trail; 12, Sue Samuelson's hand showing teaberries; 13, Helen Zimmer and microphone; 14-15, Helen Zimmer picking samples of plants for us;16,: Sphagnum moss; 17, Fungus on tree stump. They didn't know the name of fungi and mushrooms; 18-19, Upward shot of trees. Helen Zimmer (look closely) is in lower left corner of Frame 18; 20, Helen Zimmer pointing to small plants (picking teaberries?); 21, Back of Sue Samuelson's head as she walks through the forest; 22, Cocoons on tree bark; 23, Dead tree with growth on it; 24, Stream in Zimmers' cedar swamp; 25, Helen Zimmer standing in forest. Sue Samuelson is partially in the picture; 26, Wild swamp blueberries; 27, Mountain laurel (Kalmia) plant in center foreground; 28, Helen and Sue; 29-30, Pines planted by Ted Ramp. He had planned to sell them for extra income but didn't. occupations; 31-32, Weeds (milkweeds?) with Russian olive tree in background. The Zimmers commented that the Russian olive trees in the area were planted "by conservationists," and the trees turned out to be worse pests than the plants the conservationists were trying to control. Frame 32 shows Helen Zimmer looking at the weeds; 33, Fern; 34, Raccoon tracks in the sand; 35, Sue Samuelson and Helen Zimmer; 36, Fern; 37, Princess pine. architecture (outbuildings), (plant), (animal), conservation

did.unittitle:
Zimmer house, Egg Harbor City, New Jersey,
May 5, 1984

scopecontent.p: G-Devonshire; 12GT, an outlying area of G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT; Frame Nos.1-3, Table in the Zimmers' kitchen set for lunch. Coffee cake and rolls are made from a yeast dough made with chicken fat; 4, The living room fireplace. Spring flowers on the hearth have replaced some dried ones that were there in the fall; 5, The back hallway. interiors; 6-8, Dandelion wine fermenting in a crock in the corner of the kitchen. Raisins floating in the wine "help the fermentation." (Mrs. Zimmer) The cheesecloth on the bench is draped over the crock to keep dust and foreign objects out of the wine; 9-10, Homemade cream of asparagus soup. They picked the asparagus on their land. Mrs. Zimmer said that she was wondering what she could feed us that morning, and they had that asparagus. She hoped we liked it. We did. (foodways); 11, The kitchen window sill over the sink. Mrs. Zimmer stopped to point out the pine cones that had opened in the heat of the kitchen (I wasn't clear on how long they had been there -- all winter?). (plant); 12, A root showing pine mouse damage. The pine mice have short talls, run in the burrows of moles, and kill a number of plants by eating the roots. (animal); 13-14, The Zimmers' garden, showing the central irrigation pipe, a martin house and a clump of rhubarb at the far end of the pipe. yards capes; 15-17, An arrangement of rocks and plants around the base of a tree in the front yard. An old teapot used as a planter is a center of interest; 18, The garden and irrigation pipe again. See frames 13-14; 19, A flowering crab tree in the front yard. (plant); 20, A flower bed with tree, bird bath, and plants in the front yard

scopecontent.p: G-Devonshire; 12GT, an outlying area of G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT; Frame Numbers 1, The Zimmers' front yard, looking southwest from the apex of the circular drive. yardscapes; 2, The garden, showing the central raised irrigation pipe and mart in house. Overturned peck baskets protect plants from frost; 3-4, Looking past the garden irrigation pipe toward the back (east) of the yard; 5, The Zimmer front yard from across the street; 6-7, The garden from across the street, showing row of iris across the front, mailbox and newspaper box; 8, Front yard from across the street, looking southeast; 9, View further to the right (south) of frame 8; 10-11, The garden from across the street; 12-14, The Zimmer house and yard from across the street. Wide shot looking east southeast; 15, Upside down peck baskets in the Zimmer garden; 16, Front yard flower bed with bird bath, looking southeast. Compare with PFP-84-CET-002-20; 17, Hedge and pansies around southwest corner of house. (plant); 18-20, Views of an old pan planted with pansies in the front yard. re-use.

did.unittitle:
Yard walk, Egg Harbor City, New Jersey,
May 5, 1984

scopecontent.p: G-Devonshire; 12GT, and outlying area of G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT; Frame Numbers 1-2, A view of the southwest corner of the house, looking east northeast. Pansies in a planter on the ground; 3-4, Views of the plantings along the drive. Looking east northeast. Daffodils grow next to the drive. yardscapes, (plant); 5-7, Viburnum bush on the south side of the house. The Zimmers urged us several times to smell the fragrance of the blossoms, which we did each time; 8, Looking east in the back yard. The red shrub is an azalea that George planted this morning after working on the landscaping of the United Church of Christ. This shrub was left over, so George got it; 9, Bird feeder with terraced planter around the base. Back yard, looking northeast; 10-11, The back of the house, showing flower bed and cellar door; 12, A kind of work center (my term, not hers) in the back yard, directly outside the back door. The tall stumps provide hanging space for buckets and too Is, and the faucet is between them; 13, Small white flowers growing in the grass next to the work center. (plant); 14, Begonia in a pot and mandrake growing around work center; 15-16, Two views of trellis arch with a large clump of plantain lily growing at the base. There are also a couple of fronds of Boston fern starting there; 17-18, Looking east southeast in the back yard from near the kitchen window; 19, Looking west from in front of the red shed on the north side of the house. There are some piles of wood, a rather wild clump of shrubs and trees, then the garden beyond.

did.unittitle:
Yard walk, Egg Harbor City, New Jersey,
May 5, 1984

scopecontent.p: G-Devonshire; 12GT, an outlying area of G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT; Frame Numbers 1-2, Slices of white birch tree trunk dry on the bottom of an overturned boat in the Zimmers' yard. Mrs. Zimmer is in frame 1. Her husband was cutting up the wood for firewood, but when she saw the interesting shape, she asked him to cut it into slices that could be used for crafts. She gave each of us a piece. (plant); 3, Azaleas in an old coffee pot at the base of a tree. George arranged this one, but it usually Helen who does this sort of thing; 4-5, Looking toward back of house with small tree and flower bed with wind wheels made from soda cans in foreground. Mrs. Zimmer is in frame 4; 6-8, Looking north along the back of the cultivated portion of the yard. Another boat (not the one in frames 1 and 2, which is on the west side of the red shed) is up on blocks, and chicken pens are in the background; 9-10, The dining area window with bird feeders outside it. Looking west at the back of the house; 11-12, Sue Samuelson and Helen Zimmer at the back door of the house; 13, Looking southeast in the back yard toward the clothes line and bird feeder with terraced planter at base; 14, Looking east along the south side of the house, toward the back yard; 15, Wide view of the back yard looking north; 16-17, New leaves coming out on a tree in the back yard; 18, Hot box behind the house at the bottom of the hill, below the shower and pumphouse. The box is made from an old window and shelters new plants from frost in the early spring. There were some tomatoes, peppers, and flowers in the box.

did.unittitle:
Woods walk, Egg Harbor City, New Jersey,
May 5, 1984

scopecontent.p: G-Devonshire; 12GT, and outlying area of G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT; Frame Numbers 1-5, Views of pine trees and needles in the forest below the Zimmer house. Mrs. Zimmer is in frame 4; 6-8, Holly, huckleberry and sassafras grouped together near a pine tree. (plant); 9, Leaning pine tree; 10-13, Pine boughs; 14, Pine trees and clearing; 15, Mrs. Zimmer behind a tree, picking sassafras twigs for us to chew; 16-17, Huckleberry blossoms; 18-20, Fiddlehead fern sprouts in the middle of the path.

did.unittitle:
Woods walk; Cemetery visit, Egg Harbor City, New Jersey; Batsto visit, Batsto, New Jersey,
May 5, 1984

scopecontent.p: G-Devonshire; 12GT, and outlying area of G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT; Frame Numbers 1-4, Fiddlehead fern sprouts in the woods path below the Zimmers' house. (plant) Frame 1 is a closeup; 5-6, Red maple seeds; 7-8, Cone-laden pine tree. G-Egg Harbor City; 05GT Egg Harbor City cemetery, with broken green glass or dirt instead of grass; 9-11, Italian plot with a statue of the Virgin Mary and a corn husk sculpture. There were several of these on different graves around the cemetery; 12-13, Italian graves with pictures of the deceased on the stones, and with flowers (hyacinths, tulips, others, including plastic) on sand with stone borders; 14-15, Infant's grave with clump of fuschia flowers (phlox?) plus a small bunch of silk flowers (daffodils, tulips) on it. Sand background. G-Batsto; 26GT; 16-18, A family playing and flying kites on the open space outside the parking lot at Batsto; 19-20, Views of Batsto.

did.unittitle:
Visit to Batsto; Visit to Elwood and Emma's Farm Market, Elwood, New Jersey,

scopecontent.p: G-Batsto; 26GT; Frame Number 1, View of Batsto mansion with charcoal pit and visitors in foreground; 2, Visitors looking at caged animals at Batsto; 3-4, The Batsto mansion; 5, View of Batsto looking south from bridge; 6, Father and son at Batsto Lake; 7-9, Batsto river as it comes out from Batsto Lake. Pollution foam is on theater; 10-12, Views of artisans' cottages and the dirt street on which they are situated; 13-14, Corn crib at Batsto; 15, Sue Samuelson in front of old building; 16, Buildings at Batsto. G-Elwood; 12GT; 17-18, Sign on Pleasant Mills-Elwood Road: "NO DUMP ON AMATOL." See FNotes PFP-84-FET0505 for details. (We don't know if there is a proper name for the road.); 19, Emma's Market with bedding plants for sale; 20, Greenhouse at Emma's Market.

Hazel to his right; 3, Same; 4-5, Leo punching dough; 6, Leo putting bread in oven; 7-9, Putting last loaves in pan; 10-11, Between bread-baking and lunch; 12-15, After lunch, drinking coffee and conversing.

did.unittitle:
Visit to Nature's Florist Supplies, home of Hazel and Leo Landy, Nesco, New Jersey,
February 21, 1983

scopecontent.p: G-Nesco; 26GT; 1, Leo Landy in shop behind his house, holding armful of immortel (Gnaphallum Obtusifolia) aka "old field balsam", Hazel thinks because it grew abundantly near an area called "Old field" (see PFP-83-FMH1117). Aka "sweet everlasting", "rabbit tobacco" (in the mountain south; Hazel received a request for rabbit tobacco, which she was unable to fill, since she knows it as "immortel.") Note the plant specimens, dried, named and displayed over the window behind Hazel's head. They help gatherers to identify what it is they should gather). Decorative plants processed & sold by Landies; 2, Cat's paw(Eriophorum?), a swamp loving plant, gathered in early autumn; 3, Immortel (Gnaphalium Obtusifolia); 4, Italian broccoli (Cruciferae) (?); 5, Narrow leaved cattail (Typha Angustifoia)?; 6, Milkweed pods (Asclepias sp.); 7, Bayberry spray, aka common wax myrtle (Myrica sp.); 8; 9; 10, Teasel (Dipsacus s p.); 11, Landy in shop; 12, Landy in shop; 13, Baby oats; 14, Coffee grass (a sedge); 15, Golden millet (Setaria lutescens Hub) Graminae; 16, 17, Italian wheat? Wild Wheat?; 18, Leo Landy, in doorway of shop; 19, Leo Landy, in doorway of shop; 20, Hazel Landy (plant) gathering

scopecontent.p: G-Nesco; 26GT 1, Sand grass (declared off-limits to pickers, by the state); 2, Okra pods; 3, Wild mustard grass (?); 4, Lotus pod (they tried unsuccessfully to introduce these into some local streams); 5, okra pods; 6, deer skull, with antlers, hanging in shed; 7, Landy, inside his pine-cone popping shed; 8, Landy, inside his pine-cone popping shed; 9, Landy, outside his pine-cone popping shed; 10, Landy, inside curing shed. Yellow yarrow at lower left, wild mustard and pepper grass hanging from roof; 11, Peppergrass (Lepidium Virginicum) (?); 12, Sacks of pine cones, Hazel Landy, Mary Hufford (w/tape recorder) and Leo Landy in curing shed; 13, Landy walking into workshop from rear (plant)

did.unittitle:
Four-wheeling at Hidden Lakes, New Jersey,
September 18, 1983

scopecontent.p: 1-20, scenes of three-wheeling and four-wheeling at G-Hidden Lakes; 53GT. (See PFP-83-RMH-006-007 for details); 19, Mary Hufford interviewing Dave Densbower and Chris Loveland from the Bucks County (Pa) All-Terrain Vehicle club. (NB also numbers 5 and 15.); 32, Mary Hufford interviewing Nevin Ianuzzi, whose fourwheel vehicle just made it successfully through the mud hole.

did.unittitle:
Four-wheeling at Hidden Lakes, New Jersey,
September 18, 1983

scopecontent.p: 1,2,5, Mary Hufford interviewing members of the Bucks County, Pa. All-Terrain Vehicle Club: Dave Densbower, Chris Loveland. They come here for three-wheeling around the dirt roads and sand hills. G-Hidden Lakes; 53GT; 6,9,12, Mary Hufford interviewing Nevin Ianuzzi, of Medford, and his wife, who come here for four-wheeling. (See PFP-83-RMH-006-007 for details); 3,4,7,8,10,11, Various scenes of the place, a lake gouged out by a sand and gravel mining company. Land use regulations stipulate that the companies must create lakes whenever they hit water, and the various lakes they've produced throughout the area have become recreational space for three-and-four wheelers.

Note Mount Calvert in background.; 3, Carl Fleischhauer, photographer, jim Owings, Railbirder tending the skiff; 4, View of Maryland style skiff with pushpole. Railbirding on the Patuxent River, Ann Arundel County, Maryland,
September 7, 1984

scopecontent.p: 1, High tide on Ann Arundel Co. side of Patuxent River; Tree line (rear) is on embankment of old abandoned Chesapeake Beach Railroad; 2-7, Astemborski pushing Owings; 8, Astemborski; 10, Pushpole foot; 11-12, Astemborski pushing Owings. Jug Bay looking east toward Spignel farm; 13-14, Astemborski; 15-21, Owings cleans trash out of skiff before storing boat. Note use of handmade wooden balling scoop to wash out mud and reed. Looking west across Jug Bay to Jackson Landing. Stand in aluminum jon-boat made by Frank Astemborski to hold gun if marcher buoys when pushing solo. Camoflage paint on Owings' jon-boat indicates it is also used for ducking.

did.unittitle:
Pinelands Sketches
,
March 4, 1987

scopecontent.p:
Pinelands Sketches,
produced in 1987 by the New Jersey Network with support from the New Jersey Historical Commission and the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, documents railbird hunting, cranberry harvesting, cedar farming, garvey building, and fox hunting in the Pinelands area of New Jersey.

Series 5: Maps of New Jersey Pinelands

scopecontent.p:
Summary:
Includes collected map publications such as aerial, geological, land-use, oceanographic, and topological maps of the Pinelands National Reserve produced by federal, state, and local government agencies. Also includes maps created or collected in the course of fieldwork, such as hand-drawn maps of yards and residences.
